The "interest determines price of money" version of loanable funds is still false even in that presentation, because the central bank has only *one-way control*.

If the central bank raises interest rates, banks will raise theirs.

But if the central bank lowers interest rates, *banks don't have to lower theirs* -- they can simply agree to increase the spread, and make more money.

And basic cartel theory says that's what they'll do.

Why? Why is it "ridiculous?" Why is it a "waste?" Housing costs are fixed at the time of purchase. Additional rises in prices are fixed in future mortgages.

Example: you buy a home today for $250K, that's your cost as long as you own it. Sell it in 10 years for $1M, that's somebody else's cost--not yours!

The most alarming implication of proclaiming making housing available to families with difference incomes as "waste" seems to imply that fast food workers, retail clerks at Dane Reader, library clerks, dry cleaning workers, supermarket cashiers should be denied housing choices and opportunities because of their income. Surely, that isn't what you intended.

Because building good housing in great neighborhoods and making it affordable to all is the best way to secure a low crime, high achievement future, secured by those who have invested in the American Dream of home ownership, putting better opportunities for their children in reach, and reinforcing their self-determination and pride.

That doesn't seem like a "waste." It's what many call "opportunity."

I love many things about being a mom, too many to list. My current joy is being able to share (and having an excuse to read) all the wonderful children's books I either missed when I was a kid or remember fondly. Right now we are loving reading "The Mixed-Up Files of Mrs. Basil E. Frankweiler" together. My daughter and I have recently shared Mogli's adventures in "The Jungle Book," cried with Wilbur at the end of "Charlotte's Web," laughed at the humorous fables in Oscar Wilde's book of fairy tales, and wondered what exotic story Scheherazade would spin next in "The Arabian Nights." We also act out "The Raven" and my daughter practices her scary voices when saying "Nevermore." A love of reading and literature is one of the best gifts I can give her (and it's free!) and I feel blessed when our special time arrives to snuggle in bed together and dig into a book book or poem.

From Galloway and Stephens: "It hasn't been an easy road. In the weeks and months after their case first made the news, both were subject to harassment and vandalism.

"Susan and I both got hate letters, mine was vilifying atheists and telling me to stay away from Town Board meetings because it was dangerous, they didn't want to hear my pathetic views and if I didn't like Greece, I should move somewhere else," said Stephens. "Someone dug up my mailbox, smashed it and put it on top of my car. Someone dismantled a fire hydrant near my house and threw it in my pool."

Galloway said the initial backlash was frightening. At times, she said, she was so worried she had her then teenage son stay at his father's house in case there was violence.

Marginal efficiency of capital is a nice term. It's not productivity though, because it has no relationship to production levels. It's best understood as ability to extract rents; there's high "marginal efficiency of capital" if it's spent on government monopoly licenses.

Once you understand that, Keynes's words snap into sharp focus. Those who own the capital will keep expanding as long as they think they can make a rate of return (rent extraction) greater than their cost of borrowing by, say, 5%...
